commentBody: This felt hard but didn't resist mightily. It was an enjoyable solve. But some of the entries feel lame to me, like IN ARABIC.
MINNESOTA NICE üí™‚ù§Ô∏è
I liked it! A nice challenge with some twists and turns for me.

I like a nice Friday puzzle that causes mild panic in the beginning as you struggle to get a foothold, but starts coming together quickly enough that you're solve time average isn't completely wrecked. That's what this one was for me.
Took me a while to get started then it fell into place. Always have to check names. Loved the long answers. Good cluing. Great puzzle. Thanks, Evan! Have a great Friday, y‚Äôall!

Apparently, somebody fixed the toggle between Oldest and Newest.  (I did complain and was asked a whole bunch of questions, including whether I logged out and back in again, restarted the computer, and uninstall and reinstall the app, even though I told them it was an issue on a desktop, an iPhone and an iPad.)

Thank you Evan, and editors, for giving us a Friday that is not already in Easy Mode. Fine (NYT debut) clue for CIRCA, which is not to be confused with CIRCE. (HERA SAYSHI.)




The Boston cab driver says SCROD is the past pluperfect...

About the puzzle:  It seemed quite chewy as I was doing it, but my time wound up being four seconds faster than my Friday average.  So many things I didn't really know but took educated guesses and did fill-in-the-blanks after a few crosses.

A puzzle for Francis who is the epitome of MINNESOTANICE.  Dating qualifier: CIRCA, nice.  I tried sake for poke accompaniment at times, and groaned when I caught my mistake.  Lots of nice entries like FLATEARTHERS, THAIICEDTEAS and MOVIETRAILERS. Add in ICEARENA and DIAMONDEARRING, and there was a whole lot of ice in a puzzle with MINNESOTANICE at its heart.  

Seeing SCROD reminded me of an old joke: A tourist arriving in Boston for the first time, asks the cabbie on the ride from the airport, ‚ÄúWhere can scrod be had? The bemused driver replies, ‚ÄúMany people have asked me that, but that‚Äôs the first time I‚Äôve ever heard it in the past pluperfect.‚Äù
That was fun and challenging, very nicely constructed.  I'm happy whenever I can solve a late week puzzle in under 30 minutes and with no assistance.
Faster than yesterday and no lookups. Good flow, and lots of fun clues. Enjoyed.
Came for the THAIICEDTEAS, stayed for the Boston SCROD
On a day where we may be seeing some changes (we‚Äôll believe it when we see it), thanks for the MINNESOTA NICE!

"Can you fasten a rope out of metal way up in the air?"
"High zinc knot."

(Even with a first-brass ticket.)
Circe may have been onto something.

I so wanted the P-town catch to be "crabs." 

Ice arena crossing Thai Iced Tea crossing Diamond Earring -- triple ice axel! Very Winter Olympics of Evan. And a laudable effort at putting naughty ICE back in the NICE column.

As in Minnesota Nice, H3LL YEAH! ...although that, along with RAN A LIGHT and IN GOOD, well, SMH. 

Funny how the long ones filled in so easily and it was in the thickets that my time was spent.
It seemed tough and then it was done. Nicely constructed. A good workout.
THAI ICED TEAS, in sea shanty form: you‚Äôll be glad you took a couple minutes. https://youtu.be/z9T33lQAqPg

MINNESOTA NICE made me smile and immediately brought to mind Frances and HeathieJ! My cousin was named after the Fleetwood Mac song RHIANNON ‚ò∫Ô∏è I often think about music as I‚Äôm solving, so that song will forever make me think of my cousin. We also had the BEATLEs with Something. On the other hand, DIAMOND EARRING brought to mind Golden Earring üòâ Here‚Äôs Twilight Zone for your listening pleasure https://youtu.be/L3WAyRJxWpg?si=r_HaCJLlwUsyF5Xo Thank you, Evan, and keep them coming! There‚Äôs March and November this year to get another one published on Friday the 13th!!

I really liked the puzzle, but I don't understand why they would clue MINNESOTAN ICE as [Polite, friendly stereotype from the Midwest]?  

Seems kinda backwards to me.  ;-)
Joined the 1000 day streak club with this one! Definitely getting better over time. Needing less research and checks and often beating my daily average.

Another Friday grid that seems pretty decent, but so many of the clues (especially the shorter ones) were clued at such a basic level it just took the air out of the balloon, or so it seemed to me. I never really had the fun of feeling stumped, which is a shame because there were a lot of interesting longer entries. I liked the clues  for MOVIETRAILERS and DIVEBARS. But some of them like for PYROS or FLATEARTHERS just came off a bit tired or obvious despite trying to be clever. Even one of my favorite entries, MINNESOTANICE (no excuses today, Francis) just seemed clued very blandly. I don‚Äôt mind the entry INARABIC but really how many of you had to think twice about it? FIREHAT? Sure it could be part of chidlren‚Äôs costume  it so can a zillion things and not very Halloweenish‚Äîjust seemed pretty arbitrary. I did like learning about Lincoln‚Äôs fascination with ThERAVEN.
Last nit‚Äîsure, MANNA is in the Bible, but it‚Äôs physical, not spiritual, sustenance.

userLocation: Ridin' the big D of delight
commentBody:
Delightful.

That is, it would be, on Tuesday.

And not really, either, with the NE corner from my personal hell, with three adjacent trivia entries which I ended up having to look up. The constructor/editors even found a way to clue a poem I like and enjoy (possibly the only poem in English that speaks to me) in a way that stumped me.

Again we get an easy grid where knowing the trivia is the only challenge...

Where art thou, my late week misdirection? Shall I experience your uncertain rustling... Nevermore?

What a ride that was!  I went clunking over some rocky places, thinking that my crosses must be wrong, and sometimes they were and sometimes they weren't. Crave before COVET, FLATlander _ (oops) before FLAT EARTHER, and some others, but dropping in MIFFED made up for everything. The few easy clues tucked into the leftover spaces were fine, and in the end, the whole thing sparkled like a DIAMOND EARRING.

I'm looking forward to your third puzzle, Evan, and thank you so much for this one.  (I guess I'm the one who's doin' THE RAVEN.)
far and away my fastest Friday ever. liked some of the spanners

Gosh you folks can be tough on the puzzle creators. I‚Äôm just happy to finish one. I don‚Äôt know the names of tv actors, authors I haven‚Äôt read, or oddball food ingredients so I spend a bit of time with Google on Fridays and Saturdays. But it‚Äôs always enjoyable to take a quiet hour to solve the puzzles. 

So thanks to the brilliant people who give me that time to be surprised and delighted by the answers and the clues.
Had Thai Iced Tea at lunch today; what are the odds?  This one was unusually quick for me today; and I will treasure the quick solve.  Nice job.
This was a good crossword!

Honest question - do most people look things up? It kind of mystifies me when I read comments like ‚Äútoo easy; I only had to look 3 things up‚Äù. If I look ANYTHING up I mentally count it as a failed puzzle. When I look at people‚Äôs comments on the difficulty of a puzzle, I don‚Äôt know if I‚Äôm comparing my experience to those who Google. 

Didn‚Äôt look anything up in this one and I thought it enjoyable!

You'd think the story of Circe and Odysseus and his crew would be more of a cautionary tale and less a meetcute.

Sure she turned his crew into swine when they behaved drunkenly and boorishly.

But in her passion for the louts' commander (he tried to resist with Hermes's help but her charms were too powerful and he ended up betraying his fair Penelope) she ended up turning them back and everyone had a grand old time on her island (Aeaea...by the way, killer fill if it hasn't yet been used) for a year.

It's a man's world, I tell ya.
Who said I‚Äôm afraid of Friday puzzles? Fun one.
Fun puzzle!  Please tell me I‚Äôm not the only one who thought  ‚ÄúA sharp wind?‚Äù was Fart before FIFE ? ü§≠

Just gonna say: nowadays, movie trailers do indeed often give you the whole picture! They basically play out a super edited overview of the entire plot. 
Mostly it makes me want to skip the thing, if it can be summed up like that.

Can anybody help me? Sometimes when trying to solve the crossword, I need help. When I try to 'Take a peek' at the answer clues via the link, in the last weeks I always get an error message.  What do I do wrong?
It's amusing to me that taking a break and giving my brain a rest will almost always result in seeing a word that had previously eluded me and is the key to finishing the rest of the puzzle.
As a Minnesotan living in Thailand, I was pleasantly surprised to see Minnesota nice crossing paths with Thai iced tea, much like I do nearly every day. Well done!

Gosh! Felt like a Sunday to me, lots of specific knowledge which I did not possess beforehand about two types of midwesterner, pacific islanders, aegean islanders, new englanders and old celts!

Fun puzzle for a Friday!

Way out of my wavelength.
Also fix the link to the puzzle answer. It just gives an error. Not very helpful when faced with an impossible puzzle.

Finally, I flew through the puzzle but man, if I didn't get stuck right at the end with PSST and SEE. I'd made the mistake of putting cHAIICEDTEAS of course. 

Still not understanding bishop's locale.
Still, a fun little puzzle before bed.

Felt completely stuck here for about fifteen minutes and then it was like a penny dropped and I finished most of the puzzle in ten.

Hats off to MINNESOTANICE. I had some of the blanks to fill in and was thinking ‚ÄúICE are the literal antithesis of polite and friendly, *especially* in Minnesota right now,‚Äù but then the penny dropped. Bravo.

Three cheers for MINNESOTA NICE ! I am here to testify that it is a stereotype because it is true ! Just drive the freeways (and more commonly now) tollways of Dallas or Phoenix. Then go to Minneapolis and St. Paul, get on the freeways, and try your turn signal. It's like the seas part, and they invite you into their lane with a wave and smile and promise you a hot dish, dontcha know ! And now we've seen that in the face of injustice and oppression, they do not change. They are heroes. I <3 you, Minnesota !

Spelling Bee comment. In the ramp up to the saccharine and commercial Valentine's Day, the two pangrams made me laugh. I say this as a former candy peddler, so I know the holiday from a more, shall we say, money oriented perspective.

France is not obsessed with V-Day, so that's a nice change.

Yum.

My quickest Friday by *far*, 
but this puppy sparkled like a DIAMOND.
Beginning with that beautiful empty grid!

Was *every* answer fun?
Every last one?

Maybe not, 
but it feels like that.

I love that Evan Mulvihill
listed a long slew of seed entries.

Not one, not two,
a *slew."
For me and for you.
Woo-hoo-hoo!

Imma do a loop-de-loo.

Happy Friday all!
Small irritant-zinc is a mineral, not a vitamin, so strictly speaking wouldn‚Äôt it be in a vitamin/mineral supplement, not a plain multivitamin? Otherwise enjoyable puzzle.

I can I not love a puzzle which starts out with THINGY, NUTSO, PYRO, and especially HELL YEAH!--my second favorite interjection, right after "HELL NO!"?

Circe and Hera were first cousins, once removed; which is pretty far removed by the standards of Greek mythology. The family tree of the Greek Pantheon is almost as complex as that of the Coppolas.

To a person of a certain age and subculture, [Provincetown catch] suggested something else, although at least I was as negative as @john ezra (Hi, @je!)
well I read it as as Minnesotan Ice and thought that's not so nice!!

Talk about lovely bones ‚Ä¶ the three-stack across the middle and its crossing vertical two-stack ‚Äì All five answers are NYT debuts.  And excellent ones!

That is tough to pull off, and it pays off ‚Äì it lifts the puzzle out of same-old-same-old; gives it a fresh-off-the-press feeling. There are actually ten NYT answer debuts in this grid.

Lovely short answers that I like as well ‚Äì THINGY, MAHALO, MIFFED, SCROD, CIRCA.  

By the way, if your time was a little longer than usual, could be because the grid is one column wider than usual.

I like BEATLE crossing EYES, tripping off ‚ÄúThe Fool on the Hill‚Äù (And in the eyes in his head / see the world spinning ‚Äòround) and ‚ÄúCome Together‚Äù (He got joo joo eyeball).  

I also like the rare-in-crosswords five-letter semordnilap (LIVED), along with an almost six-letter one (ALETAP).

Your puzzle, Evan, was not only made well, but it played well.  This was one sweet outing. Thank you!

Although I stared at my digital clock/calendar and say FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 13th, I didn't really connect it in my mind. OY, thanks Sam for pointing it out. Now I can worry all day. Puzzle was tough today.

I took a look at this puzzle on Thursday night, answered a few three letter clues, and after that, was completely lost.  So I closed the tab and waited for the 'Easy Mode' email link.   With twenty of Christina Iverson's gentler clues, I was able to hear the happy music!  Whew!
3 down in today's mini is spelled wrong
Was sailing smugly along and then ran aground in the SE corner.  Had I known the actor I think I could have pulled it off but SIS! was a new one on me.  Oh well, a nice workout nonetheless.
Condensed milk, not evaporated milk, to make Thai iced tea.

I was doing so well until I got stuck on the area around 4A and its crosses. I was sure CHAIICEDTEAS was correct and the poke in the 4A clue I was thinking of in the context of poke bowl.  After making several trips through all the clues, checking my answers, I finally stumbled on the possibility that chai was Thai.
Chugged along nicely, with some thought, until the bottom right. Took a break, came back and it clicked. Tough one. Took me longer than my Friday average.

Spoiler alert: the earth curves when you reach the horizon.


And also, the N goes with ‚Äòice‚Äô, not Minnesota. That one dook me right in.

Was anyone else curious about the 14.54-carat Apollo Blue DIAMOND EARRING? For me, what was curious was the singular noun. I mean, don't EARRINGs usually come in pairs? If you've got 42-million dollars hanging from one ear, what do you wear in the other? https://www.naturaldiamonds.com/historic-diamonds/apollo-and-artemis-diamonds/ Apparently, you wear a similarly-sized pink diamond. For those who are still looking for a Valentine's Day gift,... Kind of amazing how small 42-million-dollars is!

Unusually tough one for me and had to cheat a bit to get through it. Probably shouldn't count it. Puzzle find today - a Sunday from March 15, 2015 by Dan Feyer with the title: "Making connections." I won't list the clues - just some of the theme answers: INSUREENOUGH INFIDELCASTRO INCANOPENER INJURYTAMPERING INFIELDGOAL INDUCTTAPE INTAKECONTROL INFANCYPANTS Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=3/15/2015&g=124&d=A See you tomorrow. ...
Twas a puzzle worthy of Friday.

HELLYEAH, MINNESOTA NICE! We've LIVED through some tough times recently, and have felt less SECURE by the day. To say we are MIFFED is an understatement. Thankfully, we didn't have to go it SOLO, as we are always here for each other. Minnesota will be an ICE ARENA no longer.

We won.

For me, 49A is clued as ‚ÄúVisitor to a fertility clinic. maybe‚Äù. Should the period be a comma?

That entire SE corner gave me such a hard time, that the confusion just seems like a cherry on top.
We need more from this puzzle creator! I've loved both of his.

I was stuck on Poke for the longest time, and it threatened my new policy of no look-ups whatsoever.

2 ideas - Poke as a fish and Poke as short for Pokemon.   

Had 'Chai Iced Tea' instead of 'Thai Iced Tea', so that was totally messing me up. 

Whew.     Good puzzle, lot of fun clues.   Would've been a shame to falter on that one.

"Once upon a midnight dreary...." There was a time when I had the whole thing. I can still do "Jabberwocky". 
Clearly I have useless knowledge taking up valuable brain space.
This was a MINNESOTANICE Friday.

I knew MINNESOTA NICE from this forum, although before doing the crossword I didn't know where it was, or how to spell it. But I still don't remember HELL YEAH, despite having watched every episode of NCIS, Law and Order, Criminal Minds and CSI. And I've have never heard of IN GOOD. Or THAI ICED TEA.

When I looked up Abraham Lincoln's poem, one he kept in his pocket and memorised,  I found "Mortality" was given as the answer, with no reference to The Raven. Odd! No reference for FIFE to anything but a musical instrument or the Kingdom of Fife in Scotland. I gather there is an alternative meaning ...

I liked lots of the clues and really enjoyed the solve,

If ‚ÄúI guess?‚Äù as the majority response to the answers in a crossword, as they were here, it‚Äôs a bad puzzle. I think the nice way of putting this that people here seem to like is, I just ‚Äúwasn‚Äôt on the same wavelength‚Äù. Hopefully we never see another from this constructor.

I wonder what happened to me chief Comment?
I did mention the entry of HELL YEAH... but others were allowed to mention it.
Now I'm MIFFED.
Loved this puzzle! Chewy but doable, great misdirects.
I‚Äôve been trying to come up with a misdirecting clue for MINNESOTANICE. How about ‚ÄúVirtue of Saint Paul?‚Äù. Except as some have pointed out, it‚Äôs not always seen as a virtue.

Streak broken at 6 (I know most of those were  easier than normal) by the top left. All of the rest was filled, but apart from SAN I had not a single square I was sure of anywhere up there.

Second Friday in a row that the top left has killed me and definitely the most common area of the grid to be a struggle for me on any day. Don't really know why, I do the clues in order.

Did not particlarly enjoy seeing THINGY, NUTSO or ALETAP when I used check puzzle to start figuring it out. Ropey clues in my opinion.
Is INGOOD an American thing?
Solid puzzle. The top left corner had me thinking this was a Monday puzzle until I got humbled. I had to leave and come back twice. Each time, I solved the clues I needed. Thanks for this one!
Thanks to 11D and 51A, I was feeling the Baltimore sports love this morning!

Loved the puzzle! Especially MINNESOTA NICE. I‚Äôm a native Minnesotan (now living in CA) and I know my people. It has been gut wrenching to see the twisted portrayal of Minneapolis in the national conversation. Minnesotans are in general steadfast, strong, generous, compassionate, and‚Ä¶nice. (Well, with a side of wicked humor and passive aggressive thought patterns,) They have shown their colors many times over the last several weeks (and years). I couldn‚Äôt be prouder. Maybe this is why I have a soft spot for Francis, HeathieJ, and many others here from the homeland. Thanks again, Evan, for a fine Friday puzzle that was very close to my heart.

What is an RDA - 22A, it‚Äôs what you should take, in brief? Can someone explain?

Also ‚ÄúALE TAP‚Äù‚Ä¶. No
MINNESOTANICE? Come on. I've watched all of Fargo. I know what's really going on behind the friendly hellos...

Count me in the Chai iced tea club.  There went ten minutes.  
Nice puzzle! Challenging and slightly off kilter.  Took me a while to pull the tiny country from my memory banks.
Thai iced teas have condensed milk, not evaporated

So, everyone's been wanting a proper Friday puzzle, have you? 
 (AKA Killer puzzle full of trickery and misdirection?
Up to here with obscurity?  Trivia upon triviality? )
Happy now?
HELL YEAH!

Anyone else trying for ICE-RINK/TIKI ICED TEA?
Anyone else nearly NUTSO by the (negative reply) that *looked* like it had two exclamation marks??
Donder und Blitzen!  We shan't soon forget Evan Mulvihill.
This was so, so, so, so good. Wow! A real stumper at first and then slowly it clicked into place. I'm awed by Evan's genius!!!! Wow! First fave of the year for sure.

I don‚Äôt like to see ICE ARENA looming over MINNESOTA NICE, but at least it‚Äôs right next to I VOTE NO.

The opportunity to vote ‚Äúno‚Äù can‚Äôt come soon enough.

"Ferruginous" is a delightful word, but I don't think I'll be able to work it into conversation any time soon.

CHAI? I can't believe that so many didn't have PSST right away, as it appears here so frequently. Also, I was under the impression that ICED TEA was a distinctly American beverage. I certainly never saw anything but the hot version when I was in China.

Anyone who had read the book "Careless People" about Facebook will be repulsed by the mention of 12D. Maybe next time find a clue for the answer "I VOTE MO" ("Campaign slogan for ex Congressman Udall?") and give us a feel good Andy Samberg clue for 12D.

Someone said something about people complaining that the new format was terrible, that they should stop whining and get used to it.

Seems like I'm spending more time looking to reveal replies to replies to replies than I am actually reading the comments, and in so doing, missing a lot of the content.

Today, there's actually an eighth-level comment in a thread between Andrzej, Francis and Matt.  Ironically, one of those three originally suggested only replying to the original post.  By the eighth level, the column is about half its original size.

Here are some suggestions:

1. A "Reveal All Replies" button.
2. Remove the "Close (number) Replies" option. Who needs to close replies?
3. Separate "Reply" and "Recommend" more.
4. Have an option to revert back to the previous version.
5. While we're at it, make Oldest the default option.

This was fun. I finished it faster than I was expecting too given how unsure I was of what I had entered. But I was viking with the constructor on this one. 

And thanks to whoever mentioned San Marino (not sure if it was here or somewhere else) in the last week or so. I'm not sure i would have come up with that as quickly otherwise. 

Oddly enough having grown up in New England, SCROD was my last fill because I had NOt instead of NOR. But the word was used as catch of the day when I was a kid. I particularly remember Legal Seafood (before expansion) having scrod listed regularly and it was always good. Back in the day before flash freezing became a thing and everything became "fresh" always.
SCROD is sometimes spelled "schrod", which is rather charming.

Late puzzle find - very unusual. A Tuesday from February 28, 2012 by Randall J. Hartman. Three grid-spanning 15 letter theme answers in that one, clued as... "Hint - first part" "Hint's next part" "Last of the hint" And those three answers were: EVERYSINGLECLUE INTHISPUZZLEHAS THIRTEENLETTERS And that was true. Can't imagine how much of a workout it must have been to manage to do that. Amazing. Here's the link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=2/28/2012&g=56&d=A ...

Either Fridays are getting easier or (at age 75) I'm getting better. Either way, thanks for a fun puzzle.

Seems my earlier comment was impounded, or lost during one of several "glitchy" periods this morning.

Lovely puzzle, but the *only* correct answer for "Someone singing 'Something'" is GEORGE.

CIRCA and CIRCE in the grid together was a nice bonus. Really enjoyed this puzzle.

Evan Mulvihill‚Äôs grid  cleverly combines the nocturnal gloom of Poe‚Äôs RAVEN with the doomsday glow of Frost‚Äôs ‚ÄúFire and Ice.‚Äù  The title of  Poe‚Äôs 18-stanza poem  (a lot longer than I remembered from my junior high school English class) occupies 11 D, while hints of Frost‚Äôs 9-line poem are scattered throughout the grid.  FIRE and ICE are overtly present in 15A and 17A, and ICE even occupies the tail end of 34A: MINNESOTANICE (recalling the initial DIAMOND of 32A). Throw in 4D: PYRO for the ‚Äúfire‚Äù theme. The shared letter I of FIRE and ICE occurs twice in all three of the long central across entries as well as in 7D and 33D , and their shared diphthong AY is found in several additional entries (ZION, EYES. HI) In all, a suitably cheery offering for the day(s) at hand.
I feel so dumb‚Ä¶can someone explain to me the PYRO explanation with the emphasis?
Anyone else have FART for 15D ? This slowed my progress ü§£

One of my first gigs out of florist‚Äôs college was operating the Zamboni at the local ICE ARENA in Tallahassee. Then home to the Tiger Sharks, I would drive the ‚ÄòBoni out onto the ice between the periods and make it smooth and supple. I‚Äôd wet it down and make it real slick. Now, anyone familiar with hockey knows that the fans tend to get a little rowdy, especially later in the game after a few pitchers from the ol‚Äô ALE TAP, and it wasn‚Äôt uncommon for them to hurl various items onto the ice in my general direction, such as empty beer cups, garments of clothing, small odd-toed ungulates, things of that nature, my brothers. Well, one game the crowd was particularly ornery and restless and somebody threw an actual Zamboni out onto the ice. A second Zamboni right onto the rink.  I had my headphones on and was rocking out to my favorite cassette tape, ‚ÄúPhil Collins Plays Stravinsky‚Äôs Greatest Hits,‚Äù not having noticed the massive obstruction directly ahead, and crashed right into it. userLocation: Ridin' the big D of delight
commentBody:
@Francis

I don't like it *so much*. It's both much simpler and much more complex than that.

First, as I have remarked here on multiple occasions, I just don't get or feel poetry in English. It feels strange and alien, generally, and either I have no idea what's going on, at all, or - in a best case scenario - I understand the language but I find it artsy and convoluted rather than special. It doesn't speak to *me*. (One of the many factors may be that in Polish, where I occasionally do get poetry, it is not metered, which in turn is often a feature in English: it's just not something I have ever learned to appreciate since it's not a thing in my native tongue).

Now, second, I simply understand the language of "The Raven", which is a good start. I also get the Romantic-era trope of longing after a dead beauty - one of Poe's most common motifs. I like how the words convey the feelings of the lyrical ego, his loss, his obsession, possibly even madness. The poem picks up pace, reflecting the growing terror. There is also the mystery in the background - who exactly was Lenore? What had happened to her? Not knowing contributes to the feeling of dark unease.

commentBody:
@Sarah f

I look up proper names, abbreviations and the like when I'm hopelessly stuck, as was the case today in the NE corner with its three adjacent trivia entries. It's either that or leaving an incomplete grid. I refuse to be defeated by stuff I haven't managed to learn along the way in my generally full and interesting life. Ultimately what's the difference between knowing some random name and looking it up? We have the internet for a reason.

For a mental exercise, imagine a grid that consists only of proper names you don't know. You wouldn't find it fair, would you? Closed-off, trivia-heavy areas of grids are somewhat like that, to me.

Finally, everybody has their own puzzle-solving standards. You have yours, I have mine. Neither is better or worse.

@Sarah f

Great question!

One I've asked myself over and over for the couple of years I've been here.

It would be silly to try to enforce any rules here, so I think we've mostly adapted a "follow your own code" here.  

But, if I may be so bold, the error you're making was the error I made for a long time:  it's a mistake to try to compare yourself to others here.  The only reason to do so is to establish oneself in a hierarchy.

And it's just not worth it.  

This is for fun, in its purest sense.

@Sarah f As a general rule, I don't do lookups, and I too feel the weight of failure on the rare occasions that I do;) My personal hack for completing tougher crosswords is that frequently the answer is far less complicated than the clue, you just have to understand the clue. Or sometimes you have to walk away for five minutes, let your brain marinate, and look at the puzzle anew. I find the experience of working out the grid that way much more satisfying than going on an internet scavenger hunt for answers to popular entertainers I no longer have the band-width to keep track of. I don't view the crossword as a competition. I view it as an exercise, from which I happen to generally derive pleasure, so I don't really think there's a wrong way to do a crossword puzzle, and I don't think doing lookups is cheating.

I'm more of a librarian-type who thinks, "I don't know the answer to that, but I know where to look." The satisfaction is in the finding of an answer. When it comes to the sports trivia questions (like the scoreboard questions that drive me insane), I will ALWAYS look those up. I have no interest in storing that info.

@Sarah f

The King of Crosslandia, our beloved liege, Will Shortz, has long said, "It's your puzzle; solve it your way."

I agree with you that using outside resources is "cheating", but that's just the way I roll.  I used to judge the way others solve, but I got over it.
 I don't think it would be possible to get a reliable survey (either in this Wordplay-realm or the greater world) about what "most people" do.

To each her/his own.
To thine own self be true.
Let a hundred flowers bloom.

And don't worry about comparing yourself to others.

@Sarah f
So glad you asked. I'll be interested in others' answers.
As for me: I'm old school, straight up. I don't look up. I'll leave a puzzle unfinished and walk away for hours, days, weeks while I wait for my brain to rev up and cough up the missing datum or for life to hand me the solve randomly. 
I think I've 'cheated' on three puzzles in the last 6 months. Came here and confessed my sins like the good Catholic girl I'm not.
And I very rarely will use "Check Puzzle" diagnostically to confirm what's correct and pinpoint where the trouble is.

But as we all say: It's your puzzle. Do it your way.

userLocation: Ridin' the big D of delight
commentBody:
@SBK

 Nope. Just nope.

There is always something *you* know or *you* can guess. Today in that silly corner I was faced with a sport guy (in the end it turned out to be a nickname I've seen before but the clue could just as well have been in Chinese), some random author of a random book (I haven't heard of either), and a title of a poem - one I knew, but again, clued effectively in Chinese. The crosses were practically zero help - the thingie for the shoes I can only name in Polish, the red plastic thing was ungettable without crosses, and I have no idea what a FIFE is. I tried to handle it on my own, but after several minutes I just looked up the trivia. That unlocked the crosses and voila. I had my fun - and I wasn't having it staring at an empty corner with 3 adjacent trivia entries.

As a native speaker immersed in American culture you have it much easier so *you* always find a foothold. I speak a language that Americans only know how to make fun of because of how it's spelled (while their spelling looks ab5urd to us), and my culture meets with yours at the Polish deli, maybe.

Also, you disagree with my method (deeply rooted in who I am, and this is not something you can possibly know better than I do) but I don't disagree with yours - maybe there's a learning opportunity for you here?

@Sarah f

With you 100%. On the rare-ish occasion I cheat at all, I do so in the app.

At the same time, I agree with 90% of the recent (last ~couple/few years) complaints about how the puzzles have gotten too easy, and also concur in presumptively attributing the motivations behind this unfortunate trend to business concerns.

But isn‚Äôt it funny how so many people like to crow prescriptively about the meaninglessness of streaks‚Ä¶and yet they use ‚Äúlookups‚Äù to preserve their own, provide well-argued justifications as to why a given puzzle so clearly deserved the lookup treatment, and often trot out the good old Shortz saw about how it‚Äôs ‚Äúyour puzzle to solve how you want‚Äù.

@The X-Phile The phrase that you more or less quote and attribute to Will Shortz was actually from the NYT article written by their second crossword editor, Will Weng, on the occasion of his retirement. What Weng wrote was: And to the solvers I bequeath a few theories about puzzles. Don't be conscience‚Äêstricken if you use dictionaries, atlases and such in doing a puzzle. It's your puzzle and you can do it any way you please. Don't let it bug you if somebody else solves a puzzle in half the time you do. That person is probably one who gulps down a gourmet French dinner too. And don't expect puzzles to teach you anything. They are for pleasure only. ___ The date of the article was Feb. 27, 1977, which was also the date of his last puzzle as an editor. You could look it up: https://www.nytimes.com/1977/02/27/archives/will-wengs-farewell-puzzle.html

@Sarah f Unfortunately people here love to brag and show off. Whether it‚Äôs true or not that some people never look things up will never be known. Honestly, it‚Äôs obvious the constructors use tools like Google, dictionaries, thesaurus, to dig up the most obscure information in an effort to make the puzzles difficult, so you shouldn‚Äôt feel guilty doing the same. You only know what you know, you know?

@Steve L Thanks for the addendum. And here is Mr. Shortz: "In answer to this question I always quote Will Weng, one of my predecessors at The Times: It's your puzzle. Solve it any way you want." https://www.nytimes.com/2009/07/19/business/media/19askthetimes.html

@Andrzej
Third generation of a Polish immigrant family here, who spoke Polish with babci as a child; my Polish language skills now are limited to knowing food names, and "please" and "thank you".

 There is no way I could do a puzzle that is not constructed in American English. 

I salute you.
